metadata.case_name: State of Maharashtra v. Jagatsing & Sheikh Ahmed

facts.text: Dongarsing, a discharged truck driver from the army, applied to District Soldiers Board, Dhulia for help in securing employment towards end of October 1955; application forwarded to Divisional Controller of State Transport Corporation at Dhulia.
Dongarsing asked by Corporation to make formal application on printed form obtained on payment of As. 0-2-0; applied in November 1955, received form on November 19, 1955.
Dongarsing met Sheikh Ahmed (respondent No. 2), employee at Jamner, who told him Jagatsing (respondent No. 1), officer at Dhulia, could secure job for Rs. 50 bribe.
Dongarsing went to Dhulia with Sheikh Ahmed, met Jagatsing on November 25, 1955; settled Rs. 50 bribe, Rs. 25 paid immediately, remaining Rs. 25 paid about December 9, 1955.
Dongarsing informed end January or beginning February 1956 that application rejected.
Dongarsing asked Jagatsing to return Rs. 50 or secure job; Jagatsing said money paid to others, but another Rs. 50 might procure job; new form filled and given to Jagatsing.
Dongarsing suspicious, approached anti-corruption department; trap laid, Rs. 30 currency notes with anthracene powder given to Dongarsing.
On February 20, 1956 at 3 p.m., Dongarsing passed Rs. 30 to Jagatsing; Jagatsing had money in hands, threw down on challenge; anthracene powder on thumb, two fingers and seam of right pocket.
Currency notes picked up, panchnama prepared, investigation led to prosecution of Jagatsing and Sheikh Ahmed.
Jagatsing denied guilt, said no concern with appointments, not in position to help Dongarsing.
Sheikh Ahmed denied guilt, said only helped fill form, never told Dongarsing to pay bribe.

Trial court (Special Judge) found prosecution proved case beyond doubt for Rs. 30 payment as illegal gratification; but Sheikh Ahmed not guilty of abetment as not present at last payment, letter Ex.29 not handed over; acquitted both as Jagatsing not public servant under s.43 Transport Act.

State appealed to Bombay High Court (Criminal Appeal No. 2 of 1959), judgment May 17, 1960; High Court accepted Rs. 30 bribe payment, but acquitted relying on State of Ajmer v. Shivjilal, no averment of public servant to be approached.
Jagatsing senior assistant in traffic section, State Transport Corporation, Dhulia.

legal_issues.text: Whether Jagatsing was a public servant within the meaning of s.21 IPC read with s.43 of Road Transport Corporation Act, 1950.
Whether ingredients of s.161 IPC proved, particularly whether averment needed as to public servant to be approached, relying on State of Ajmer v. Shivjilal.

petitioner_arguments.text: Prosecution proved Rs.30 payment as bribe to Jagatsing for securing job; Jagatsing public servant; ingredients of s.161 IPC satisfied without needing to specify other public servant as he was in the office making appointments.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.161 IPC; distinguished State of Ajmer v. Shivjilal

petitioner_arguments.text: s.43 Transport Act deems officers public servants under s.21 IPC even for bribe-taking.
petitioner_arguments.legal_basis: s.43 Road Transport Corporation Act, 1950; s.21 IPC

respondent_arguments.text: Jagatsing had nothing to do with appointments; taking bribe not acting/purporting to act under Transport Act.
Sheikh Ahmed only helped fill form, no abetment.

court_reasoning.text: Distinguished Shivjilal case: there bribe for service to another public servant at different location; here Jagatsing in same office, money for official act (appointment) by his office, applies to different part of s.161 IPC.
court_reasoning.key_observation: No need to specify other public servant when accused in office where act to be done.

court_reasoning.text: Jagatsing not public servant under s.21 IPC r/w s.43 Transport Act as bribe-taking not 'acting or purporting to act in pursuance of provisions of this Act or any other law'; drew analogy from s.197 CrPC cases (Gill, Hori Ram, etc.) where bribe not official duty.
court_reasoning.key_observation: Clear words of s.43 limit public servant status to acting/purporting under Act; bribe never so.

court_reasoning.text: Even if not directly appointing, as senior assistant in traffic section, could get official act done.
court_reasoning.key_observation: s.161 covers for himself or other person in office.

holdings.text: High Court erred in applying Shivjilal ratio; s.161 proved but Jagatsing not public servant under s.21 IPC r/w s.43 Transport Act for bribe offence.
Officers/servants of Corporation public servants only when acting/purporting under Act; bribe-taking not so.

precedents_cited.relevance: High Court relied on it for needing averment of other public servant; SC held inapplicable as facts differ (accused in same office).
Bribe under s.161 not acting in discharge of official duty for s.197 CrPC sanction.

precedents_cited.case_name: Hori Ram Singh v. The Crown
precedents_cited.relevance: Distinguished s.409 (no sanction) from s.477A (sanction needed); approved in Gill.

precedents_cited.case_name: Shreekantiah Ramayya Munipalli v. State of Bombay
precedents_cited.relevance: s.197 not too narrowly construed; official act even in dereliction if facilitates offence.

precedents_cited.case_name: Amrik Singh v. State of Pepsu
precedents_cited.relevance: Sanction under s.197 if act directly concerned with official duties, claimable as by virtue of office.

statutes_cited.name: Indian Penal Code, 1860
statutes_cited.relevance: Charge under s.161; public servant definition in s.21 r/w Transport Act s.43.

statutes_cited.name: Road Transport Corporations Act, 1950
statutes_cited.relevance: Deems corporation officers public servants under s.21 IPC only when acting/purporting under Act.

statutes_cited.name: Code of Criminal Procedure, 1898
statutes_cited.relevance: Analogy for official duty; defect in charge curable unless failure of justice.

outcome.summary: Supreme Court dismissed the State's appeal by special leave, upheld Bombay High Court and trial court acquittal of Jagatsing and Sheikh Ahmed; held Jagatsing not public servant for s.161 IPC as bribe not under s.43 Transport Act.

key_quotes.text: "taking of a bribe cannot under any circumstances be shown to amount to acting or purporting to act in pursuance of any of the provisions of the Transport Act or of any other law."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Core holding on why not public servant under s.43.

key_quotes.text: "The High Court therefore was not right in applying the ratio in Shivjilal's case to the facts of this case, for it was not necessary on the facts of this case to indicate who was the other public servant."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Distinguishes precedent, reverses High Court on s.161 ingredients.

key_quotes.text: "It is not every offence committed by a public servant that requires sanction for prosecution under section 197 of the Code of Criminal Procedure, nor even every act done by him while he is actually engaged in the performance of his official duties."
key_quotes.speaker: court
key_quotes.significance: Quotes Amrik Singh to explain official duty test applied analogously.
